affiliation.orgName: US Army Engineer Research and Development Center
US Army Engineer Research and Development Center

analytic.title: Isogeometric analysis of free-surface flow

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: Free-surface flow Level set method Global mass conservation Isogeometric analysis Higher-order methods Finite elements Fluids Residual-based variational multiscale method (RBVMS) Turbulence

div.p: This paper presents the first application of isogeometric analysis, a new computational technology built on higher-order and higher-continuity basis functions employed in Computer-Aided Design and computer graphics, to the computation of free-surface phenomena described using the level set approach. The method is based on the variational framework that is suitable for discretization by standard finite elements as well as the basis functions employed in isogeometric analysis. The underlying numerical formulation globally conserves mass and preserves a sharp air-water interface for the entire length of the simulation. The numerical tests indicate that the proposed methodology gives an accurate description of the free-surface behavior in both quasi-steady and dynamic regimes. Furthermore, very good per-degree-of-freedom accuracy is obtained when higher-order and higher-continuity isogeometric discretizations are employed in free-surface computations.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: In this work we aim to develop a robust and accurate methodology for air-water free-surface flows in complex geometrical configurations that has no limitations on the motion of the free surface. We are interested in a class of large-scale applications in coastal, marine, and offshore engineering. That is, we would like to have a unified methodology that is able to accurately represent the entire range of free-surface behavior, from the smooth, quasi-steady free-surface, as in the case of surface ship wakes at low-to-moderate Froude numbers, to the violent free-surface motion with topological changes, as in the case of sloshing liquids in tanks or wave impact on offshore structures. As a result, we will base our developments on the level set method [33,36,38], which is an interface-capturing methodology [40], and which puts no limitations on the complexity of the free-surface flow behavior and the nature (laminar, transitional, or fully turbulent) of the underlying fluid flow regime.

In Ref. [27], we developed a discrete formulation of air-water free-surface flow using the ideas of the residual-based variational multiscale (RBVMS) methodology for Large Eddy Simulation of incompressible turbulence [3]. Although the discrete variational formulation in [27] was, in principle, suitable for discretization using variable-order finite elements as well as other, non-polynomial based approaches, the numerical examples in [27] were limited to piece-wise linear finite elements. Although good accuracy and robustness of the approach were clearly shown, it was conjectured that the formulation would give even better performance if higher-order and higher-continuity discretization were employed. In this paper we demonstrate that this is indeed the case by using isogeometric analysis [24] based on non-uniform rational B-splines (NURBS) [34], in conjunction with a slightly modified version of the formulation proposed in [27], to solve free-surface flow problems.

The paper is outlined as follows. In Section 2, we briefly state the continuous formulation of the free-surface flow problem based on the level set method. In Section 3, we give a summary of our space-and time-discrete formulation of free-surface flow, and present a simplification of the technique developed in [27], which leads to a more efficient computational procedure without compromising the accuracy of the original method. The accuracy of the method largely relies on its global mass conservation properties and a stable, sharp air-water interface representation. In Section 4, we give a brief review of the isogeometric analysis with an emphasis on recent developments in the field, and its performance in applications involving pure convective phenomena, fluid flow, and turbulence. In Section 5, we present a suite of computational examples. These examples were chosen so as to highlight the various aspects of the proposed approach. In the first computational example we employ a well-known, pure convection benchmark problem to compare the performance of C 0 -continuous linear finite elements and C 1 -continuous quadratic NURBS. This numerical example shows that a significant per-degree-of-freedom accuracy increase may be obtained for higher-order NURBS as compared to low-order finite elements for pure convection phenomena, as well as representation of small-scale features on relatively coarse meshes. The second test case involves a 3D dam break over an obstacle. The free-surface solution exhibits a cascade of large and small scales, topology changes and wave breaking. However, despite the complexity of the solution field, the methodology is able to accurately predict the free surface evolution and time-dependent pressure loading on the obstacle even on very coarse discretizations. In the last example, we compute the free-surface flow around the Wigley hull at Froude number 0.25. This test case generates a quasi-steady free surface without wave breaking and topological changes. The NURBS discretization produces a smooth free surface and accurate wave patterns and elevations as compared to the experimental data. In Section 6, we draw conclusion and outline future research directions.

div.head: Continuous formulation
div.p: We consider the continuous form of the level set method for incompressible air-water flow (see, e.g., [33]). Let X 2 R d ; d ¼ 2; 3 be the problem domain and let @X denote its boundary. We denote by @X d the essential or Dirichlet part of @X, and by @X n the natural or Neumann part of @X. We also denote by u : X ! R d the flow velocity. Given u, we define the inflow and outflow parts of @X in a usual manner as
div.formula: @X À ¼ fx 2 @Xju Á n < 0gð1Þ
div.p: and
div.formula: @X þ ¼ fx 2 @Xju Á n P 0g;ð2Þ
div.p: where n is the unit outward normal.
We define a scalar function / : X ! R, which is convected with the flow as
div.formula: @/ @t þ u Á r/ ¼ 0 in X:ð3Þ
div.p: The function / acts as a level set in a sense that its zero level divides the spatial domain into two parts,
div.formula: X w ¼ fxj/ðx; tÞ > 0gð4Þ
div.p: and
div.formula: X a ¼ fxj/ðx; tÞ < 0gð5Þ
div.p: the water and air subdomains, respectively, and the interface between them is given by
div.formula: C ¼ fxj/ðx; tÞ ¼ 0g:ð6Þ
div.p: The two-fluid flow in X is governed by the incompressible Navier-Stokes equations
div.formula: Lðu; pÞ ¼ q @u @t þ qu Á ru þ rp À r Á 2lr s u ¼ qf ; ð7Þ r Á u ¼ 0;ð8Þ
div.p: where Lðu; pÞ is the Navier-Stokes momentum operator, p is the pressure, r s u is the symmetric gradient of the velocity field and f is a body force per unit mass. Typically in free surface applications f corresponds to a gravitational acceleration vector. The fluid density and viscosity are given by
div.formula: q ¼ q w Hð/Þ þ q a ð1 À Hð/ÞÞ;ð9Þ
l ¼ l w Hð/Þ þ l a ð1 À Hð/ÞÞ;ð10Þ
div.p: where H is the Heaviside function

and q w , l w , q a and l a , denote the density and dynamic viscosity of water and air, respectively. Provided the appropriate initial and boundary conditions are set, the above equations constitute a complete model of the two-fluid flow at the continuous level.

div.head: Discrete formulation
div.p: In this section, we present our fully discrete free-surface formulation. We first discuss space discretization of the individual subproblems and then present our time integration strategy. The work follows closely our approach in [27], but with some simplification in the treatment of the level set equation. This simplification results in a more efficient computational procedure, which nevertheless retains all the attractive features of the original method.

div.head: The space-discrete formulation of the Navier-Stokes equations
div.p: Let V h denote the discrete solution space for the velocity-pressure pair {u h ,p h } and let W h denote the discrete weighting space for the linear momentum and continuity weighting functions {w h , q h }. We employ the following space-discrete form of the Navier-Stokes equations: Find fu h ; p h g 2 V h such that 8fw h ; q h g 2 W h , Bðfw h ; q h g; fu h ; p h gÞ þ B vms ðfw h ; q h g; fu h ; p h gÞ þ B wbc ðfw h ; q h g; fu h ; p h gÞ À Fðfw h ; q h gÞ ¼ 0: ð12Þ

In the above equation, the semilinear forms B, B vms and B wbc give the Galerkin, residual-based variational multiscale (RBVMS), and weak Dirichlet boundary condition contributions to the discrete formulation. They are defined as follows:
Bðfw; qg; fu; pgÞ ¼ w; q
div.formula: @u @t X þ w; qu Á ru ð Þ X þ ðq; r Á uÞ X À ðr Á w; pÞ X þ r s w; 2lr s u ð Þ X À ðw; qðu Á nÞuÞ @X À n ;ð13Þ
B vms ðfw; qg; fu; pgÞ ¼ fu Á rw þ rq=qgs M ; Lðu; pÞ À qf ð Þ X þ ðr Á ws C ; r Á uÞ X
div.p: þ fu Á ðrwÞ T gs M ; Lðu; pÞ À qf X À ðrw; qs M fLðu; pÞ À qf g s M fLðu; pÞ À qf gÞ X ;
div.formula: B wbc ðfw; qg; fu; pgÞ ¼ w; qðu Á nÞu þ pn À 2lr s u ð Þ @X d þ À2lr s w À qn; u À g ð Þ @X d þ Àqðu Á nÞw; u À g ð Þ @X À d þ ðws B ; u À gÞ @X d :ð14Þ
div.p: F({w,q}) in Eq. ( 12) is a linear functional, which collects body forces and surface tractions as
div.formula: Fðfw; qgÞ ¼ ðw h ; qf Þ X þ ðw h ; hÞ @X h :ð16Þ
div.p: In Eqs. ( 12)-( 16), (Á,Á) A denotes an L 2 -inner product over the domain A, taken element-wise. The last term in the Galerkin semilinear form (13) stabilizes the discrete formulation (12) at the natural boundary in the presence of local flow recirculation (see, e.g., [7]). In the weak boundary condition terms (see Eq. 15) g is the velocity boundary condition.

The RBVMS turbulence model was originally proposed in [3] and successfully employed in [23,1,10,11] on a variety of turbulent flows. The subgrid-scale stabilization parameters s M and s C in Eq. ( 14) are defined as in [3]. The formulation is augmented with weakly enforced boundary conditions, originally proposed in [8], which improve the flow solution accuracy in the presence of under-resolved turbulent boundary layers. The exact expressions for the weak boundary condition penalty parameter s B may be found in [8,10,11].

For very high Reynolds number flows, to further stabilize the discrete formulation, we employ discontinuity capturing, which results in adding the following terms to the left-hand-side of Eq. (12) þðrw; j dc r s uÞ X : ð17Þ Several definitions of j dc , the discontinuity-capturing viscosity, are given in [41]. We find that for very large Reynolds number flows and pure convection the use of discontinuity capturing provides the necessary stability and robustness of the numerical procedures.

The theoretical foundations, implementation details, and performance on a variety of applications of the above methodology is discussed at great length in [3,1,10,11]. The interested reader is encouraged to consult these references.

div.head: Convection of the level set and regularization of the material parameters
Let V h
div.p: s and W h s to be the discrete solution and weighting spaces for the scalar level set convection equation. The spacediscrete formulation of the level set / h is stated as: find / h 2 V h s , such that for all weighting functions g h 2 W h s ,
div.formula: Bðg h ; / h Þ þ B vms ðg h ; / h Þ þ B wbc ðg h ; / h Þ þ B dc ðg h ; / h Þ ¼ 0;ð18Þ
div.p: where the semilinear forms are defined in direct analogy with the incompressible Navier-Stokes equations as
div.formula: Bðg; /Þ ¼ g; @/ @t þ u h Á r/ X ;ð19Þ
B vms ðg; /Þ ¼ u h Á rgs; @/ @t þ u h Á r/ X ;ð20Þ
B wbc ðg; /Þ ¼ Àðgfu h Á ng; / À gÞ @X Àð21Þ
div.p: and
div.formula: B dc ðg; /Þ ¼ ðrgj dc ; r/Þ X :ð22Þ
div.p: Eq. ( 21) provides weak enforcement of the inflow boundary condition, with g being the desired value of the level set function at the inflow. Eq. ( 22) is the discontinuity-capturing operator.
The material parameters for the two-fluid system at the discrete level are computed as
div.formula: q ¼ q w H e ð/ h Þ þ q a ð1 À H e ð/ h ÞÞ;ð23Þ
l ¼ l w H e ð/ h Þ þ l a ð1 À H e ð/ h ÞÞ;ð24Þ
div.p: which are regularized versions of Eqs. ( 9) and (10). The regularized smoothed Heaviside function (compare with Eq. ( 11)) is defined as,
div.formula: H e ð/Þ ¼ 0 i f / 6 Àe; 1 2 1 þ / e þ 1 p sin /p e À Á À Á if j/j < e; 1 i f / P e; 8 > < > :ð25Þ
div.p: where e is the interface half width given by
div.formula: e ¼ a r/ h kr/ h k Á G r/ h kr/ h k ! À1=2ð26Þ
div.p: and G is a second rank metric tensor defined as
div.formula: G ¼ @n @x T @n @x ;ð27Þ
div.p: with @n @x being the inverse Jacobian of the mapping between the elements in the parent and physical domains. Eq. ( 26) gives the interface half width equal to the a-multiple of the mesh size in the direction orthogonal to the air-water interface, as desired.

div.head: Re-distancing of the level set and mass conservation
div.p: The previous two sections presented the numerical counterparts of the Navier-Stokes and level set convection problems. In this section, we introduce additional numerical technology to overcome the two shortcomings associated with the direct application of the above discrete procedures, namely, excessive interface distortion and lack of global mass conservation. In order to maintain long-time integration accuracy and overall stability of the formulation, we insist that the level set function satisfies the signed-distance property, which controls the width of the interface layer see Eqs. ( 25) and (26), and that the global mass is conserved for the duration of the simulation. Our level set re-distancing and mass conservation procedures are described in what follows.

div.head: Re-distancing
div.p: To ensure the level set function satisfies the signed-distance property, we make use of the Eikonal partial differential equation in air and water subdomains subject to zero boundary conditions at the air-water interface, that is,
div.formula: kr/ d k ¼ 1 in X a ; ð28Þ kr/ d k ¼ 1 in X w ; / d ¼ 0 on C:
div.p: Before discretizing in space, we introduce a ''pseudo-time'' variable t and re-state the above problem as: Given /(x, t) from Eq. ( 3), find / d that satisfies
div.formula: @/ d @ t þ signð/Þðkr/ d k À 1Þ ¼ 0;ð29Þ
/ d ðx; 0Þ ¼ /ðx; tÞ:ð30Þ
div.p: At the steady state, the above problem produces a new level set field / d with the signed distance property and zero level set coincident with that of /. This re-distancing approach was first proposed in [38], and employed in [32,27] for finite element computations of free surface phenomena. The semi-discrete variational formulation of the re-distancing problem is as follows: given / h (x, t) from Eq. ( 18), find
div.formula: / h d 2 V h s , such that 8g h d 2 W h s : g h d ; @/ h d @ t þ S e ð/ h d Þðkr/ h d k À 1Þ ! X þ S e ð/ h d Þ r/ h d kr/ h d k Á rg h d s; @/ h d @ t þ S e ð/ h d Þðkr/ h d k À 1Þ ! X þ rg h d ; j dc r/ h d X þ g h d k pen H 0 e ð/ h d Þ; / h d À / h X ¼ 0:ð31Þ
div.p: The above formulation is the SUPG method [12]
div.formula: S e ð/ h d Þ ¼ 2H e ð/ h d Þ À 1:ð32Þ
div.p: The last term on the left-hand-side of Eq. ( 31) explicitly penalizes the deviation of the interface from its initial position. The penalty parameter k pen is multiplied by H 0 e ð/ h d Þ, which scales as 1/h in the interface layer and is identically zero away from the interface.

div.head: Mass balance
div.p: Convection and re-distancing of the level set function inevitably lead to the lack of global mass balance. To restore the global mass balance we adopt a formulation, which constitutes a simplification of our original procedure proposed in [27]. In [27], in addition to a convection of H, a separate regularized nonlinear projection, resulting in a reaction-diffusion partial differential equation, was solved for a perturbation of the level set / 0 that restored the global mass balance. In this work, we take the original formulation as a point of departure and explicitly set / 0 to a global constant in X, which leads to the following nonlinear, time-dependent, scalar equation: find
div.formula: / 0 2 R, such that Z X @H e ð/ h d þ / 0 Þ @t dX ¼ Z @X H e ð/ h d þ / 0 Þu h Á nd @X:ð33Þ
div.p: This equation can be derived form the integral statement of global mass balance,
div.formula: Z X @q @t dX ¼ Z @X qu h Á nd @Xð34Þ
div.p: and the definition of the mass density q given by Eq. ( 9). Because the resulting update / 0 is usually small, we effectively force the interface to move in the direction of its normal. A similar idea of moving the interface in the direction of its normal is employed in [29]. However, because the authors do not use the level set method, the numerical implementation is not as straight forward.

div.head: The fully discrete algorithm
div.p: As in our original reference [27], we adopt a staggered solution strategy in which the Navier-Stokes step is followed by the convection step with re-distancing and mass conservation.

We use the generalized-a method [25] to advance the fluid from time t n to t n+1 with density and viscosity taken at t n . The midpoint rule is employed to advance the level set equations to time t n+1 using the newly computed flow velocity.

The level set is then re-distanced in pseudo-time using the backward Euler method. Because of the penalty terms present in Eq. (31), we are able to take large pseudo-time steps without loosing the interface position predicted by the convection step. The level set is re-distanced at every physical time step using a small fixed number of pseudo-time steps. The choice of the pseudo-time step is based on the convective CFL for the Eikonal equation, and is computed as
div.formula: D t ¼ 2c min x2X S e ð/ h Þ r/ h kr/ h k Á GS e ð/ h Þ r/ h kr/ h k ! À1=2 :ð35Þ
div.p: The parameter c = 1 in Eq. ( 35) corresponds to the CFL of unity. In the computations, we usually take c = 6. To further accelerate convergence to the steady state, the pseudo-time step is increased with a decreasing nonlinear residual of the re-distancing equations.

The level set is then adjusted to satisfy global mass balance by approximating Eq. ( 33) using the midpoint rule on the time interval. The resultant scalar equation is solved using Newton's method. Convergence to machine precision is typically achieved within three Newton iterations.
Once / h d and / 0 are obtained for the time level t n+1 , / h at t n+1 is set to / h d þ / 0 , and we proceed to the next time step.

div.head: Isogeometric analysis, fluids and turbulence
div.p: To discretize the fluid and level set equations in space, we employ isogeometric analysis. Isogeometric analysis was recently proposed in [24] in an effort to bridge the gap between Computer-Aided Design (CAD) and Computer-Aided Engineering (CAE) through a unified representation of the design and analysis geometry. Isogeometric analysis makes use of the basis function technology developed in CAD and computer graphics (CG) fields, and applies it to problems in computational science and engineering. Isogeometric analysis has many features in common with FEA, such as the underlying variational framework, the isoparametric concept, locally supported basis functions, and possibilities for h-and p-refinement. However, isogeometric analysis offers richer possibilities, as compared to the FEM, for geometry modeling and solution representation. A unique feature of isogeometric analysis not shared by standard finite elements is the so-called k-refinement, in which the order and continuity of the basis functions are elevated simultaneously. Smooth basis functions that are C 1 -or higher-continuous can be directly employed to discretize higher-order differential operators (see, e.g., [22] for a recent application of isogeometric analysis to modeling of phase separation governed by the Cahn-Hilliard equation).

We make use of isogeometric analysis based on NURBS (non-uniform rational B-splines) [34,13]. NURBS are a standard basis function technology used in CAD and CG, and the first, and most widely employed computational technology in isogeometric analysis. Recent applications of isogeometric analysis include solids, structures, fluids, and fluid-structure interaction, and may be found in the following references [3][4][5][6][9][10][11][14][15][16]1,43,44]. NURBS are built from B-splines through a projective transformation [20], and inherit their superior approximation power [6,19]. Quadratic and higher-order NURBS, unlike standard finite elements, can represent all conic sections exactly, which include circular and cylindrical shapes often used in engineering design.

Although the development of isogeometric analysis was largely motivated by geometry representation in analysis, this new basis function technology was shown to be beneficial for various physical applications, and, in particular, fluids and turbulence. The first application of NURBS-based isogeometric analysis to fluids was reported in [3], where, in conjunction with RBVMS, superior per-degree-of-freedom accuracy was achieved for homogeneous and wall-bounded turbulent flows. In the recent paper [1], standard C 0 -continuous quadratic finite elements were compared to C 1 -continuous quadratic NURBS using a challenging wall-bounded turbulent flow test case. Quadratic NURBS gave significantly more accurate per-degree-of-freedom results, especially for the velocity fluctuations statistics. NURBS-based isogeometric analysis, in conjunction with RBVMS and weakly-enforced boundary conditions, also produced very good results for rotating [2] and separated [11] turbulent flows.

In this work, isogeometric analysis is applied to free-surface flow modeled using the level set approach. It will be demonstrated in the next section that the use of higher-order and higher-continuity NURBS basis functions significantly improves the accuracy of the free-surface level set procedures.

div.head: Numerical results
div.p: In this section we present three numerical test cases that illustrate the performance of the proposed methodology. The first test problem is a pure advection case in which the flow velocity is prescribed. Because no flow solution is required, we do not enforce the distance function property of level set function. We use this test case to perform a per-degree-offreedom comparison between bilinear finite elements, and C 1 -continuous quadratic NURBS. Three levels of mesh refinement are performed to asses the convergence properties of the method. The second test case was first presented in [28] and involves violent free surface motion. The third test case involves a quasi-steady free surface generated by a flow around the doubly parabolic Wigley hull. Both free-surface cases are computed using quadratic NURBS. The computational results indicate that: 1. C 1 -continuous NURBS have superior accuracy to low order finite elements for pure convection, and 2. The proposed level set formulation, in conjunction with higher-order isogeometric NURBS discretization, is able to accurately represent free-surface phenomena in both violent and quasi-static regimes using a modest number of degrees of freedom. We note that in all computations the discrete mass balance is satisfied to machine precision due to Eq. (33).

div.head: Stretching of a circular disc
div.p: This test case is used to compare NURBS and standard low-order finite elements on a pure convection problem. The problem setup and parameters are taken from [35]. The computational domain is a unit square and / h is initialized such that its zero level set is a circular disc of radius 0.15 centered at (0.50, 0.75). The flow velocity is time-dependent and is prescribed to be u = (u, v), where

This velocity field stretches the disc into a very thin spiral. However, at t = 4, the flow reverses and the spiral is deformed back into a perfect circle at t = 8. We use meshes of 40 Â 40 and 80 Â 80 elements and compare bilinear FEM with quadratic NURBS. Note that for a given mesh the quadratic discretization has only one extra degree of freedom in each Cartesian direction with respect to the linear mesh. Fig. 1 shows the zero level set of / h at t = 4 for all meshes. An overkill solution is plotted for comparison. Note that the tail of the filament is thinner than one element for both discretizations. Linear finite elements show a greater deterioration of the solution, especially in the thin parts of the spiral. Quadratic NURBS are able to better represent the solution than their linear counterparts. Fig. 2 shows the final condition at t = 8, which is expected to be a perfect circle. Linear 40 Â 40 solution gives a relatively smooth shape, however, the deviation from a prefect circle is significant. Results improve greatly for the 40 Â 40 quadratic NURBS and the resultant shape is much closer to a circle. The 80 Â 80 linear mesh gives results that are slightly worse then for the 40 Â 40 quadratics. The 80 Â 80 quadratic discretization produces a final zero level set shape that is barely distinguishable from a circle.

Convergence under mesh refinement of both linear FEM and quadratic NURBS is shown in Fig. 3, where in each case we added a computation on a 160 Â 160 element mesh. We report the L 1 -norm of the difference between the initial and final shapes and the L 1 -norm of the difference between initial and final distance functions localized to the interface. The norms are defined as follows,
div.formula: L 1 ðH e Þ ¼ 1 L Z jH ð/ h 0 Þ À H ð/ h T ÞjdX;ð38Þ
div.p: and where L is the interface length and X int is the e-neighborhood of the interface given by
div.formula: L 1 ð/Þ ¼ max x2X int / h T ðxÞ À / h 0 ðxÞ ;ð39Þ
X int ¼ fxjx 2 X; / h 0ðxÞ
6 eg:ð40Þ
div.p: The L 1 (H e ) and L 1 (/) error measures are similar to those reported in [18] and [31], respectively. Table 1 and Fig. 3 show that the error convergence rate is approximately p + 1 for the L 1 (H e )-norm and p for the L 1 (/)norm, where p is the polynomial order. For both norms we obtain an extra order of convergence for quadratic NURBS with respect to linear elements. These results are very encouraging and indicate that the quality of the advection scheme, a key ingredient in the level set method, may be significantly improved when the higher-order and higher-continuity discretizations are employed.

div.head: Dam break with obstacle
div.p: The problem consists of a 1.22 m Â 1 m Â 0.55 m column of water, initially at rest, that collapses under the action of gravity and impacts a stationary object. The computational domain is a rectangular box with dimensions 3.22 m Â 1 m Â 1 m. The object has dimensions 0.161 m Â 0.161 m Â 0.403 m and is placed at the back end of the tank. The problem setup is shown in Fig. 4. Experiments for this test case were performed at the Maritime Research Institute Netherlands (MARIN), and the data is often used to validate free-surface software for marine engineering applications (see, e.g., [28,17,27]).

We employed two quadratic NURBS meshes for this simulation, consisting of 32 Â 16 Â 16 (coarse) and 64 Â 32 Â 32 (fine) elements for the problem domain, and 2 Â 6 Â 3 and 4 Â 12 Â 6 elements for the object. Nearly uniform discretization is employed in all Cartesian directions, and the fine mesh is an h-refinement of the coarse. We would like to note that the meshes are very coarse for this simulation. For instance, computations of the same test problem using linear finite elements reported in [17,27] use approximately double the resolution in each direction for obtaining similar quality results. This more than offsets the additional computational effort associated with quadratic NURBS, rendering the quadratic NURBS more computationally efficient then their linear counterparts.

Free-slip and no-penetration boundary conditions are applied on all surfaces, including the top of the tank. The no-penetration boundary condition is imposed strongly. The time step is set by an adaptive time stepping procedure [37,42] in order to maintain the advective CFL close to 0.5. This lower value of the CFL is chosen to maintain the good accuracy of the higherorder spatial discretization that is employed in conjunction with a second-order time stepping algorithm. Figs. 567show the snapshots of the evolution of the free surface at different times during the simulation. Fine mesh results are presented in the figures. The free surface exhibits violent motion with topological changes. At the earlier stages in the simulation, the water impacts the container, runs up the back wall and touches the top of the tank. At the later stages, wave breaking occurs and is well represented on the fine mesh. All these features are in very good agreement with the experimental results reported in [28].

Coarse and fine mesh results are shown together for comparison in Fig. 8. While the large scales of the flow are very similar between the two meshes, the fine mesh allows for better resolution of the fine-scale features, like the details of the water run-up on the back wall and wave breaking.

Fig. 9 shows time history of pressure at several points on the object surface (see Fig. 4 for the locations of the pressure data points). Results for both coarse and fine meshes are presented. In both cases, the overall agreement between the experiment [28] and our computations is excellent, especially given the coarseness of the meshes employed. The peak pressure loads are also predicted with very good accuracy. The fine mesh results are generally in closer agreement with the experimental data than the coarse mesh results. One also needs to keep in mind that a point-wise pressure is a quantity that has very high sensitivity to small perturbations in the input data and hence cannot be predicted with high certainty. Fig. 10 shows the time history of water heights at several points along the length of the domain (see Fig. 4 for the locations of the water hight data points). The agreement with the experiments is remarkable. As in the case of the pressures, the fine mesh results for the water heights are in closer agreement with the experimental data than the coarse mesh results.

div.head: Free surface flow around a Wigley hull at Fr = 0.25
div.p: As the third test case we consider free surface flow around the Wigley hull at Fr = 0.25, where Fr ¼ ku 1 k= ffiffiffiffiffi gL p is the Froude number, ku 1 k is the inflow velocity, L is hull length, and g is the gravitational acceleration. The hull geometry is defined by two double parabolic surfaces, given by the formula
div.formula: ¼ 0:5B 1 À 4 x L 2 1 À z D 2 ;
div.p: À 0:5L P x P 0:5L;
div.formula: À D P z P 0;ð41Þ
div.p: where B and D are beam and draft, respectively, where L = 1 m B = 0.1 m and D = 0.0625 m. The computational domain is taken as 4 m Â 2.05 m Â 0.75 m in the stream-wise, horizontal, and vertical directions, respectively, and the water level is placed at 0.5 m. The experimental results for this case are taken from [26]. The problem was investigated numerically in [21,30]. We would like to note that in [21,30] the authors used incompressible Euler equations and a moving mesh technique, and did not simulate the air domain, which is typical for this class of problems. In this work, incompressible Navier-Stokes equations with viscosity and density parameters of air and water, and weakly imposed no-slip boundary conditions are employed.

div.head: Boundary conditions and the treatment of hydrostatic pressure
div.p: In contrast to the previous test case, this problem involves inflow and outflow boundaries. At the inflow, uniform flow velocity and linear in the vertical direction level set function are prescribed. At the outflow, a boundary condition must be imposed that takes care of the hydrostatic pressure component. We handle the hydrostatic pressure component as follows. We perform the pressure field decomposition into its hydrostatic and fluctuating parts as
div.formula: p ¼ p H þ p:ð42Þ
div.p: With this decomposition, the pressure gradient term in the Navier-Stokes equations becomes where the last equality derives from the hydrostatic solution of the Navier-Stokes equations. In Eq. ( 43), q 0 is the fluid density distribution in the hydrostatic state, and g a is the gravitational acceleration vector. The linear momentum equation can now be written as We use this form of the momentum equation for the discretization of the Wigley hull problem, which allows us to employ a simple zero traction outflow boundary condition for the fluid. We simulate the Wigley hull problem on one half of the domain with symmetry boundary conditions. The problem mesh is comprised of 96 Â 48 Â 32 quadratic NURBS elements in the stream-wise, horizontal, and vertical directions, respectively, and is shown in Fig. 11. Note that because the quadratic discretization is employed, the hull geometry is represented exactly.
div.formula: rp ¼ rp H þ rp ¼ rp þ q 0 g a ;ð43Þ
q @u @t þ qu Á ru þ rp À r Á 2lr s u ¼ ðq À q 0 Þg a :ð44Þ

div.head: Computational results
div.p: To develop the free-surface solution, the problem was started from a hydrostatic state. The Navier-Stokes simulation with a fixed free surface was first performed to develop the flow around the hull. Then the free surface was ''released'' and the computation continued until no noticeable changes in the wave pattern were observed. The quasi-steady water surface wave pattern is shown in Figs. 12 and 13. We would like to note that although the free surface attains a quasi steady-state solution, the flow, especially in air, is quite unsteady and turbulent. Despite the fluid turbulence, the water surface remains remarkably smooth. Fig. 14 shows the water line along the length of the hull. The results compare quite well with the experimental data reported in [26].

div.head: Conclusions and future work
div.p: A free-surface formulation based on the level set method, proposed in [27], is employed in conjunction with the NURBSbased isogeometric analysis. The discrete formulation is modified for increased computational efficiency by adopting a simplified global mass conservation procedure. A simple circular disc stretching test case clearly shows the advantages of using higher-order and higher-continuity NURBS discretizations to approximate pure convection phenomena that lie at the heart of free-surface approaches based on the level set method. Computations of the dam break and Wigley hull test cases clearly showed that the proposed framework is able to accurately predict the free surface behavior in the quasi-steady as well as dynamic regimes, where the latter involves wave breaking and free-surface topology changes. Higher-order and highercontinuity NURBS discretization also proved to be efficient for free-surface flows, in that accurate results may be obtained on very coarse meshes.

Because the underlying basis function technology in isogeometric analysis (e.g., NURBS) are standard in computer graphics and animation, this work presents an opportunity to employ the same basis function representation for computation and rendering of the free-surface results for the purposes of animation. (See, e.g., [33] for the use of level set methods in computer graphics.).

Future work will entail the extension of the computational methods to fluid-object and fluid-structure interaction simulation, using the Mixed Interface-Tracking/Interface Capturing approach (see [39]). Application of the above methodology to large-scale simulation of coastal hydraulics, and ocean and marine engineering and science applications are also envisioned.

div.head: Acknowledgements
div.p: The authors thank Prof. A.L.G.A. Coutinho for his valuable input on the dam break test problem. We also wish to thank the Texas Advanced Computing Center (TACC) at the University of Texas at Austin for providing HPC resources that have contributed to the research results reported within this paper. Support from Teragrid, the J. Tinsley Oden faculty fellowship program, and the Navigation Systems and Military Engineering 6.1 research programs of the US Army Corps of Engineers are gratefully acknowledged. This research has been supported in part by an appointment to the Postgraduate Research Participation Program at the US Army Engineering Research and Development Center, Coastal and Hydraulics Laboratory (ERDC-CHL) administered by the Oak Ridge Institute for Science and Education through an interagency agreement between the US Department of Energy and ERDC. The corresponding author was supported through ARO Award W911NF-10-1-0247. Permission was granted by the Chief of Engineers to publish this information.
